Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2011 01:34PM Enjoyful wrote: Wow, I'm so sorry you have to go through this!  If you still feel uncomfortable with your doctors after tomorrow's appointment, by all means get a second opinion.  I had one at Sloan-Kettering and was very happy that I did.  You won't have to go through all of the testing all over again - they'll request the biopsied tissue, pathology reports, and scan results from your doctor.  And if you do decide to change doctors, as I did, you won't be starting at square one. A lot of my doctor-related anxiety abated when I found a new, confidence-inspiring doc.  I hope you can find the same. Hugs to you! E
Posts.Title: This Nightmare is Getting Out of Hand - Any Help? 37antiques ebann

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2010 10:24PM Enjoyful wrote: Monica, I went for a second opinion at MSK and was quite impressed with the thoroughness of their exam and investigation prior to issuing a second opinion.  I was also pleased with their opinion - they favored more aggressive treatment than my ex-onc because of my relatively young age and otherwise good health.  In their opinion, even though I'm stage IV I'm potentially curable because of the small amount of metastatic disease.  I'm so glad I went to them!  My ex-onc did not recommend anything aggressive because I was "Stage IV, and going to die anyway."  I found a local onc who shared MSK's opinion and I'm very happy with him. RobinWendy's experience with wait times, etc., was similar to my own.  They also forgot about me and left me in the waiting room for two hours after my appointment with the onc, when I didn't need to wait around at all!  I also had some difficulty getting the formal, written report from them.  BUT, I really liked the opinion I got! Best of luck to you! E

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2010 08:15PM Enjoyful wrote: Hi, Suzanne - Of course you're freaking out!  That's a huge burden on top of everything else you're dealing with. I don't know your specific circumstances, but maybe this applies (from http://www.dol.gov/ebsa/cobra.html): "To qualify, individuals must experience a COBRA qualifying event that is the involuntary termination of a covered employee's employment. The involuntary termination must generally occur during the period that began September 1, 2008 and ends on May 31, 2010.... The premium reduction applies to periods of health coverage that began on or after February 17, 2009 and lasts for up to 15 months. See Continuing Extension Act of 2010." This seems to say that as long as your qualifying event occurred before May 31, 2010, you're still eligible for a total of 15 months of benefits.  They're just not giving that benefit to anyone who had a qualifying event AFTER May 31.  Somebody please correct me if I'm wrong! Best wishes, Suzanne! E

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 10:44AM Enjoyful wrote: Oh gosh, I can understand why you're frightened!  Here's a link about potassium levels; the page also lists reasons for low potassium.  The link is here: http://www.labtestsonline.org/understanding/analytes/potassium/test.html  And some of the reasons for low potassium, taken from that link, follow: Decreased levels of potassium indicate hypokalemia. Decreased levels may occur in a number of conditions, particularly: In diabetes, your potassium may fall after you take insulin, particularly if your diabetes had been out of control for a while. Low potassium is commonly due to "water pills" (diuretics); if you are taking these, your doctor will check your potassium level regularly. Additionally, certain drugs such as corticosteroids, beta-adrenergic agonists such as isoproterenol, alpha-adrenergic antagonists such as clonidine, antibiotics such as gentamicin and carbenicillin, and the antifungal agent amphotericin B can cause loss of potassium. Good luck!   Please let us know how you're doing! E

Posts.Title: Clinical Trial for ER+ Receptor Degradation Bestbird 20130502

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2013 05:50AM Enjoyful wrote: I'm back! Susan, thanks for the offer but my boyfriend's practically a Boston native.  We had a great time cycling around Boston Saturday morning! And now for the trial - I'm quite impressed with the trial and the young doctor running it.  Is it just me, or are doctors getting younger?  Anyway, ARN 810 showed great promise in animal models.  Of course, making the leap into humans is another story.  There are four people in the first cohort.  Three achieved stability after just a few months and the other has moved to a different trial after no results.   Side effects are hot flashes and some nausea ONLY.  No hair loss, joint pain, muscle pain, bone pain, diarrhea, zits, mouth sores; all of which I have on my current trial.  I'm so tempted to jump the crap ship of a clinical trial I'm on now and fly over to ARN 810! In the meantime, Mass General is testing my tumor for protein and gene abnormalities so they can see which future treatments would be most effective against my cancer.  Now THERE'S a novel concept.  *eye roll* I'll be happy to answer any questions you all have.   Susan

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2010 05:08AM Enjoyful wrote: Hi there! Wow, so sorry about the car accident on top of everything else!  PET scans can light up for a bunch of different reasons.  I had some lymph nodes light up, but a biopsy revealed normal lymphatic reaction to some sort of infection.  More recently, my thymus lit up; they think it's "thymic rebound," a reaction to the chemo, but they're going to watch it. There's usually an SUV score on the PET scan report.  I believe that the higher the number, the more likely it's cancer.  My thymus had an SUV of 3.7, if that helps.  If your doctor thinks it's inflammation, then likely the SUV is low or there were other non-cancer indicators.  I hope it's "just" inflammation!  Best of luck to you! E

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2011 07:38AM Enjoyful wrote: Good morning, Krissi! Taxotere is a difficult chemo for a lot of us, but a lot of us also have very good results with it.  I think the worst side effect is neuropathy in hands and feet, but you can also expect blackened finger nails, body aches, mouth sores, and fatigue. Someone on these boards suggested sucking on ice and putting your fingertips in ice water to either prevent or lessen the severity of the fingernail and mouth sores issues. It really worked for me!  For me, taxotere worked very well.  I had mets to my neck and I could feel them shrinking after the first dose of taxotere, and I'm still NED two years later. Best of luck to you, Krissi! E
Posts.Title: Good news with taxotere? krissi Momine

Posts.Content: May 2, 2013 04:08PM Enjoyful wrote: Within the last month, I had a PET/CT and MRI that showed multiple lesions on my spine.  A CT-guided biopsy of the largest was negative for cancer.  My doctor spoke with the radiologist and confirmed proper placement of the biopsy needle, and the tissue they retrieved was sufficient for a biopsy. Nevertheless, my oncologist said that false negatives are common in bone biopsies and he believes it's cancer.  So we're going ahead with a clinical trial. This sucks!  Biopsies are supposed to be definitive!

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 12:55PM Enjoyful wrote: I'm so sorry, Cat.  As you can see by the answers, you're not alone!  You have a horde of angry, mammogram-betrayed women marching along with you. I'd always been told I had dense breast tissue but was laughed at when I asked if it was a risk factor and/or a problem.  My mammos and ultrasounds were clear for years, including the ones performed 6 months before diagnosis.  The mammos and US missed SIX freakin' tumors in my right breast.  Once they knew I had cancer, though, a follow-up MRI showed everything.  Too late for me - diagnosed at stage III and now stage IV. I've heard that mammograms are only 60-70% accurate.  Isn't that a failing grade?  I think we can thank our health insurance companies for paying only for mammograms and not the MRIs that could have saved us a lot of heart ache. E

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2010 06:47PM Enjoyful wrote: Mammaglobin-A DNA vaccine.  Most breast cancers over-express the protein mammaglobin-A.  The vaccine is supposed to generate an immune system response to that protein so that your body kills the cancer itself.  It's being run out of Washington University in St. Louis.

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2009 07:55AM - edited Dec 19, 2009 07:58AM by Enjoyful The truth is they don't really know what causes cancer or what causes it to return.  I'm sure it certainly can't hurt to maintain a healthy body weight and do things in moderation but I don't appreciate what come across as scare tactics. Just to let you know, before diagnosis I had always been active, had a healthy body weight, never smoked, drank rarely if at all, had a baby before I was 30, breast-fed my daughter, began menstruation after age 12 (you know, all the low-risk factors) and I still got cancer.  Just days shy of my 5th cancerversary, it came back even though I continued what I considered a healthy lifestyle.  This doesn't mean it's hopeless and you should go out and abuse your body, but sometimes crap happens and we have no control over it. So please don't blame yourselves for your cancer.  Guilt can't be good for our health either!  Going forward, lose the weight because you'll feel better mentally and physically and because you'll be healthier overall.  Good luck and good health! E Edited to add:  I wondered as I read that article whether dosage was the issue.  If they're using the same dosage of chemo and/or hormonal and other therapies for everyone, wouldn't it make sense that overweight persons would have poorer results?
